docs.title: Welcome!
docs.text: A mental model is a compression of how something works. Any idea, belief, or concept can be distilled down. Like a map, mental models reveal key information while ignoring irrelevant details. Models concentrate the world into understandable and useable chunks. - https://fs.blog/mental-models/

docs.title: Attack Life Cycle -> RINSE & Repeat
docs.text:
Attackers always RINSE & repeat:

  • Reconnaissance - Gather information to assess value & vulnerabilities aka System Susceptibility
  • Infiltrate Networks - Get into target networks aka Threat Accessibility
  • Spread Laterally - Stay within target networks aka Threat Capability to stay undetected
  • Execute Objectives - Results to compromised Confidentiality (stolen), Integrity (tampered) & Availability (denied access) of data & networks. For Cyber Physical systems, it can lead to life threatening scenarios.

Understand how attacks can be disrupted by design & not by reacting to problems & adding more Tit-for-Tat controls.

Click here to dive deeper...

docs.title: Tactics Techniques & Procedures
docs.text:
The original context of "Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures" (TTPs) is rooted in military terminology, specifically within the Department of Defense. TTPs are used to describe the employment and ordered arrangement of forces in relation to each other (tactics), the non-prescriptive methods used to perform missions or tasks (techniques), and the standard, detailed steps that prescribe how to perform specific tasks (procedures).

Click here to understand how it is applied in Cyber Security...

docs.title: Notions
docs.text: The word "Notions" effectively combines the essence of both "notes" and "thoughts." It conveys the idea of ideas or concepts that are recorded or contemplated, making it a fitting choice for a term that encapsulates both elements.

docs.title: Attackers RINSE & repeat...
docs.text:
At the center of this life cycle, are the Necessary & Sufficient conditions of any successful attacks.

  • Reconnaissance - Gather information to assess value & vulnerabilities aka System Susceptibility
  • Infiltrate Networks - Get into target networks aka Threat Accessibility
  • Spread Laterally - Stay within target networks aka Threat Capability to stay undetected
  • Execute Objectives - Results to compromised Confidentiality (stolen), Integrity (tampered) & Availability (denied access) of data & networks. For Cyber Physical systems, it can threaten lives.

docs.title: Direct vs Indirect Access to Objectives
docs.text:
Directly from 1.Recon to 4.Execute Objectives -> Poor web-server configuration leads to exposure of unprotected sensitive files that can be downloaded by anyone. Can't even consider this as an attack, low hanging fruits for adversaries!

From 1.Recon to 2.Infiltrate Networks -> Attackers use LinkedIn to figure out who are the HR executives, send deceptive emails to lure them (Phishing) to click on malicious links or execute malware. Just need one employee to give attackers that chance to gain control over a HR asset when the malware infects like a Patient Zero & persists within that endpoint. Why go through all that trouble when attackers can buy access into corporate VPN?

First scenario clear illustrates the 3 conditions, valuable information in the form of files are there left exposed, anyone can explore such web-server directories without being noticed. Attackers just need to scan a range of Internet addresses to find vulnerable servers.

Success or failure of cyber-physical attack depends on Necessary and Sufficient prerequisites. Attacks are effective only when all conditions are fulfilled, yet it will fail if any single condition is disrupted. For instance, when employees are vigilant, they report the phishing emails. With robust multi-factor VPN authentication, 1st factor of ID & password sold on dark web is less threatening.

docs.title: Disrupt Attack Life Cycle by Design instead of...
docs.text:
Reacting to yet another vulnerability announcement, another patching exercise (e.g. Microsoft Patch Tuesday) or worst, automatic updates that disrupted millions of Windows hosts. Basically stuck in a Chase-After-Bad posture, which is unending & costly.

Designing with Threat Accessibility in mind enables us to thwart attacks efficiently while maintaining both usability and security.️

What about the other two conditions; System Susceptibility & Threat Capabilities ? They contribute to our ending pains!

  • Keeping up with vulnerabilities by patching is very challenging & sometimes disastrous. I'm not suggesting a "don't need to patch", but rather advocating caution and careful consideration before implementing any changes to production systems.️
    • Hypothetically, if Windows were free of bugs, there would still be numerous system tools & mechanisms susceptible to misuse by attackers.
    • Those are inherent characteristics rather than software defects. Complex operating systems, including Windows, Linux, MacOS & mobile ones, are all susceptible to such vulnerabilities.️
    • Vulnerabilities cover beyond software bugs, but includes poor designed features that can be abused.
    • Preference is given to securing "Crown Jewels" in our asset evaluation, while attackers typically focus on exploiting low-priority assets for their initial entry point.️
  • Threat actors are extremely motivated, creative & resourceful. They use free or cheap tools to evade costly controls & monitoring operations at a fraction of the cost!

Threat Accessibility can be addressed by design, instead of reacting to yet another new vulnerability or offensive method. When designed well, even vulnerable assets are harder to reach.

docs.title: Avoid Password Only Access
docs.text:
Single-factor authentication refers to the process of verifying identity through the use of one identifier, such as an email address or username, coupled with a password.️ Upon obtaining these credentials, there is a significant risk that password reuse will grant Threat Actors access to the majority of associated services.️

As illustrated earlier:

  • Malicious actors have the ability to gain unauthorised access to email accounts and assume control over online identities.️
  • A corporate VPN relying on single-factor authentication grants attackers unfiltered access to an organization's internal resources.️

We can disrupt such unauthorised access with either Multi-Factor authentication or replacing passwords with passkeys.

docs.title: Avoid Admin Ports Exposure
docs.text:
Admin ports like SSH, RDP, VNC should never be accessible over the Internet. Even access to web admin pages should be limited to few IP addresses whenever possible.

There are many freemium software private networks like ZeroTier, Twingate, Tailscale & the likes to limit access. Instead of using public Internet address, simply configure such remote admin services to use private network address accessible to a few admin endpoints.

docs.title: Avoid Tit-for-Tat Controls
docs.text:
The Crowdstrike Channel File incident is a prime example of Tit-for-Tat control. Updates are needed to counter whatever new offensive techniques.

These controls are primarily designed to counteract attack techniques and address hosts or network vulnerabilities. Due to the ever-evolving nature of offensive tactics & techniques, continuous updating is essential to keep pace with new threats - thereby classified as reactive or Tit-for-Tat controls.️

More examples of signature-based Tit-for-Tat Controls (non-exhaustive) :

  • Anti-virus
  • Web App Firewall
  • Network Intrusion Detection

Encryption facilitates evasion for malware. Malicious network traffic can be obscured through encryption, with a significant proportion of Internet communications encrypted.️

docs.title: Apply Design Thinking & ALC
docs.text: Now that you have some idea of the pitfalls to avoid, we are ready to use this scenario of a tech refresh for a hypothetical law firm, to come up with a more usable & secure network, by applying Design Thinking & Attack Life Cycle mental model.

docs.title: Recap
docs.text:
• Attackers will RINSE & repeat within this Attack Life Cycle.
  • They can attack directly at services or indirectly, by getting into target networks & work their way within to meet their offensive objectives (steal, tamper & deny access to data & systems).
  • Although network attacks seem like a very complex topic, there are only three conditions necessary for any successful attacks.
  • It is sufficient to disrupt attack by dealing with any one of the conditions, but keeping up with system vulnerabilities by patching & changing offensive techniques is very difficult for us.
  • We can disrupt attacks by design to make systems usable & accessible to legitimate users but much harder to intrude, instead of just reacting to vulnerabilities & threat techniques.
  • A concrete scenario was used to illustrate how it can be done.

docs.title: TTPs
docs.text: In cybersecurity, TTPs have been adapted to describe the behaviour of threat actors and the structured framework for executing cyberattacks. Understanding TTPs is crucial for identifying, analysing, and responding to security threats. Tactics refer to the strategic (WHAT) objectives of an attacker, techniques are the (HOW) methods used to achieve these objectives, and procedures are the specific (WHEN) steps taken to execute the techniques.
